entry.title: Combined summary - Gradual transition to an alternate proof without a hard fork.
entry.summary: Various proposals have been put forth to transition from PoW to PoB in Bitcoin. Erik Aronesty proposed the idea of transitioning from PoW to PoB in a soft fork on the bitcoin-dev mailing list. The proposal assumes a PoB model that accurately reflects the investment in and development of ASICs for maintaining miner incentives. The transition would begin with validating nodes requiring PoB in addition to PoW in a soft fork, which would make mining more expensive and lead to a gradual drop in PoW usage. Eventually, PoB would be required at 100% of the "required work" to mine on a predefined schedule.The author proposes a long transitionary period for switching consensus protocols, including switching to a different hash function for proof of work. This period should be long, perhaps years, to give miners time to switch over. There would need to be some manually determined estimate of equivalence hard coded into the software as there would be no trustless mechanism to relate the amount of work done between the two mechanisms. The idea is to have a smooth switch over from blocks created by the old mechanism to blocks created by the new mechanism, eventually reaching 0% for the old and 100% for the new. However, this change could be fraught with perils if the miners using each mechanism don't cooperate to ensure that equivalence is set fairly.A hard fork may be necessary to prevent issues during the transition period, but a soft fork is also possible. It is important to have a long transitionary period and a manually determined estimate of equivalence to ensure a smooth switch over. However, the risk of miners not cooperating exists, and more work needs to be done to ensure a successful transition.During a recent conversation about cryptocurrency, a proposal was made to transition from a proof-of-work (PoW) system to a proof-of-burn (PoB) system for mining. The proposal suggested an alternative required proof such as quantum PoW or PoB in a back-compatible way, which would eliminate the need for a hard fork. However, Jeremy expressed concern that without hard deprecating PoW, all old miners would become "toxic waste." Another potential obstacle raised during the conversation was the problem of one miner turning on an S9 and ramping up the difficulty for everyone else. To address this issue, it was suggested that a 99% reduction in PoW would be more than enough. By making this change, the transition to a PoB system could be accomplished effectively without causing any major disruptions to existing mining operations. Overall, the discussion centered around the best way to move away from PoW as the primary method of mining for cryptocurrencies. While there were concerns raised about the potential impact on existing miners, the proposal offered a viable alternative that would allow for a smooth and gradual transition to a new system. With careful planning and consideration, it may be possible to make this shift without causing significant disruptions to the cryptocurrency ecosystem.
